column3: There are lots of stalls you can buy water and food from , although it is very expensive relative to the cost of these things on the outside .
There are lots of guides which will show you around but remember to only pay 1 / 2 or a 1 / 3 of what they initially offer you it for .
Besides the amazing sights , we were shocked how open the animal abuse is , which appears to mostly be to donkeys .
Many are tied up against rocks with no food or water in the sun .
The donkeys used to transport guests appear mostly ok , although they are hit etc to move faster .
The issue is with the donkeys used by the locals to move their goods in and out of the site .
If you wonder away from the path you will see these poor animals up close .
We saw a donkey which was tied up in the sun , absolutely covered in flys with scabs over its face .
Another donkey near by had a serious breathing problem and had cuts around its legs .
When you arrive in Petra you will see a lot of dogs .
We wondered why there were so many and then eventually we learnt why - they are used to scare the donkeys to move faster .
The owners make a noice to encourage the dogs to bark at the donkeys and bite the donkeys legs .
We saw it up close several times , dogs biting the legs of donkeys .
If you visit Petra I am sure you will see this to .
Count of many donkeys have scabs , sores and missing fur around their legs .
Unfortunately the vast amount of visitors after they have walked several Km in the hot sun will overlook the animal abuse and pay for rides on the donkeys .
We saw a small child hitting a donkey on its head with a long stick as hard as he could several times until we shouted at him to stop .
When there were no owners around we managed to get a few pictures for evidence .
After our recent visit to Petra , we wish we had read the reviews beforehand as any beauty of the site was overtaken by the vast amounts of animal cruelty we witnessed .

They race the single horse carts with tourists up the steep hill and if the horses do not go fast enough then they whip them with electrical flex , the worst example being the stiff type that you would wire up a house with .
They just want to get up and down as quickly as possible to maximise there takings with no consideration to the poor animals or the people on the walk-way .
There are examples of broken pieces of the cable all the way down where they have been used so intensely , bits have broken off and are just lying about .
I noted the postcards depict the horses sedately walking up the hill but this is nothing like the chariot race we witnessed , with horses foaming at the mouth struggling to cope in the heat .
We will never return and have posted this as we would not wish to spoil your holiday as much as it did ours .
We will never return to Jordan or Petra as the mentality is engraved in their culture to abuse these animals .
We booked a 3 - day private tour of Jordan with Tourist Jordan that was subcontracted to Jordan Experience .

Every thing went well for the first day in Amman and Jerash , until our guide announced that he was now summoned by the Company to guide a large group the following day and a new guide and driver would be assigned to us and would pick us up at our hotel at 08:30 in Petra .
No one came for us , the following morning , all clients of the hotel had departed from the Hotel and we were left stranded .
The hotel manager offered to drive us to the office of Jordan Experience in Petra , which would open at 10:00 am .

The hotel manager finally reached Zeyad Rawadieh , from the Jordan Experience Office , who apologized for the misadventure and asked us to make our way to the downtown area with our suitcases ( 3km ) , where a guide would be organized to give us a tour of Petra .
We eventually linked up with the new guide whom had just been called , but no driver had been assigned yet for our next destination ( Wadi Rum ) .
At the end of the Petra tour we met with the manager of Jordan Experience Office , Zeyad , who was completely unapologetic .
He eventually assigned a new driver to take us to Wadi Rum .
On our route to Wadi Rum , well outside Petra , our driver announces us that he had to return to the office in Petra as we had to sign a piece of paper .
When we got to the office in Petra , the manager Zeyad stated that I had to sign a customer satisfaction memo before continuing with our Tour to Wadi Rum .
I replied that would certainly not sign a customer satisfaction form , when we were completely forgotten in the morning .
He replied that we would not leave his office until I had signed his customer satisfaction memo .
I then offered to sign but with the caveat that would annotate his form with a detailed description of events .

After annotating his customer satisfaction form with a true description of events , he tore the statement to pieces and started to threaten me that I would stay in his office all night until I declared that I was satisfied with his services .
After playing cat and mouse in his office , I finally gave in and signed under duress his form .
In most countries , this level of threat and blackmailing would be sufficient to close any business .
In fairness , the personnel from the same company in Amman and Aqaba were charming , punctual and competent .

I suspect that the issue with the Jordan Experience ( Petra Office ) and in particular its manager is that they have become highly complacent with tourists flooding Petra , taking tourists for granted and concurrently unable to deliver during peak periods .
You can not but be at awe with the beauty of Petra .
It is so unfortunate though that the way it is run is a disgrace to this incredible heritage .
We were a party of 7 adults and all of us left exhausted by the local hustlers from both adults and unfortunately kids who were trying to either sell us stuff or talk us into riding horses .
They were aggressive and would not take no for an answer .
The price per person holding a foreign passport is JOD 50 which is a lot especially having to go through such a terrible experience .
One thing that is amazing though is that the locals , both adults and children , spoke good English .
The young locals who dress like the Pirates of the Caribbeans could be a great attraction to see had they behaved themselves , but they were behaving badly and abusing the animals .
Jordan is a beautiful country , the people are very nice and the food is wonderful .
Unfortunately , I will advise friends not to visit Petra until the mess is sorted out .

Must you visit Petra though , make sure you have a RELIABLE TOUR GUIDE who would not only explain its wonders and the habits of its inhabitants back then , but also , would be able to give you a better experience by pushing away those hustlers and scammers .
The site was overtraded with vendors , begging kids , dogs , cats , horses , donkeys , camels and charlatans expecting hand outs !
Go to the dead sea , go to the wadis , DO NOT GO TO PETRA !
I have traveled a lot , and travelling through India and Asia , you do come across the tourist hustlers , child workers , annoying sellers shouting at you , animal abusers and so on .
No , but maybe its part of the deal , I can understand it and have fun with it .
Well my 68 Year old mother and my mother in law would call it being harassed , but me , for my part , I can deal with it .
But , mark my words , one day someone will die at Petra .
From the entrance to the the first sight , there is a narrow canyon , and especially in the afternoon , the horse carriages go up and down with insane speed not giving a damn about anyone walking .
I am certain people have been hurt there , we had to jump out of the way a couple of times ourselves .
In the wider parts of Petra , there is a lot of animal traffic , but at least not too much risk .
From the end part , up to the monastery there is a small path , mostly steps , going up .
It was me , a 35 year old male with my wife and our 66 year old mothers walking up .
For some completely insane reason , they allow donkeys carrying tourists up and down .
Now , all that might be insane , but not yet a death trap .
We were walking up , and after 5 minutes , 2 kids around 8 to 10 years old with donkeys chased their other donkeys up hill with tourists .
The two front donkeys with tourists pushed my mother in law from the trail into a one meter deep ditch .
the donkey fell in there with her and his hoofs were trampling next to her body and head before he ran further out of the ditch and up the stairway .
The bigger problem is , that 200 meters further up the ditch is 10 meters deep and then what ?
Talking to the tourist police , they said this happens all the time .
One day someone will die on the way to the monastery , mark my words !
Petra is fantastic , it takes your breath away and is a must to see .
The problem with the place is the pushy rude and threatening people ( they claim they are bedouins , the locals call them gypsys ) .
They really get angry if you do not pay them EXTRA .
They abuse their animals and they will not take no for an answer .
Kids no older than 10 are allowed to wander around the site getting in your way and begging .

They also target single woman and elderly and bully them into buying from themI spent 4 lovely days before going to Petra and saw the real Jordanians are honest friendly and genuine people who are shocked at the impression these gypsys give tourists .
Although the site is fantastic , until they control the rampent harrassment from thr gypsys the the rating stays poor .
They beat their horses badly to get to the end faster ( and more trips ) .
The ride is shockingly violent and dangerous for anyone with a sore back , You will have a sore back afterwards .
My horse was whipped so badly he collapsed and when I reported it and gave the carriage number the tourist police ignored me .
This place has great potential but is being ruined by poor management and unscruplerous touts .
The initial walk through the siq is pleasant but then come the mules , carts which fly past and can be scary .
The guys who are touting for you to use their animals for rides followed us for much of our walk and kept asking if we wanted a ride and that it would be tough to get to the end .
In all honesty once we had seen the treasury it all became a little boring which gave us another reason to head back .
I would not go again and you are not missing much if you do not go .
Just Google the images and maybe go for a Bedouin desert camp instead .
Our family was going to be there for two days but left after one .

The place is really nice , as it is one of the historical places and one of the seven new wonders of the world , but the problem is that the place is horribly managed and you need to walk all the way until the end to find cafes and restrooms .
Avoid visiting in August and try to visit it between April and June .
The rating here is for the experience , obviously the site is beyond such trivia .
Petra the place would have got 5 stars and then some .

This is a real problem , I was one of many , many tourists who were harassed constantly , sworn at , sexually propositioned , followed , and generally made extremely uncomfortable in an almost sacred setting .

One guide was physically attacked by them in front of the tourist police , who did absolutely nothing , and my guide was accosted more than once when I refused to get on a poor mule , or not buy a trinket which was made in China and completely overpriced .
One lady was reduced to tears as they tried to coerce her onto an horse , another was scammed and these are just the people I happened to talk with .
I visited in the low season when I guess the locals need tourists money more urgently , but even so-I am not sure how bad things have to get before the situation is addressed .
If you have visited all of the other major historical sites in the world then maybe consider a visit to Petra .
This is one of the worst managed sites I have ever visited and also one of the most expensive .
Jordan as a country should be embarrassed by the lack of management of this site .
They rip off visitors with an exorbitant entry fee and then abandon them to endless unwanted attention from local scam artists .
I have visited Aztec sites in Mexico , temples in Thailand , the Pyramids in Egypt and the Valley of the Kings in Luxor .
I would re-visit these in a heartbeat but I will never be back to Petra .
The history is amazing and I do not regret visiting as it has always been on my list of things to do , but for a repeat visit to this part of the world I would choose the Pyramids .
My partner and I could not believe the blatant abuse happening in Petra , in front of many many uncaring tourists .
We witnessed , on multiple occasions , locals throwing rocks at donkeys when they cried out ( in pain ) ?
The worst for me was seeing a camel walking strangely before realising his front feet were tied together .
Maybe it is us , being our first time at an attraction that works off the back of animal tourism , I guess I am just not as good at ignoring it as plenty of other tourists were .
If you have legs that work , do not take a horse , donkey or camel .
The sellers inside can be quite annoying , very persistent , which I anticipated .
There are also school age children selling items , not surprising but it would be good if Petra would do something about this .

It was great to see Petra , it is very interesting , however my partner and I had a two day pass included in our Jordan pass ( the best way to visit Jordan , as Petra entry is also very expensive ) and while we were intending on spending two full days , we arrived at 7:30 on the first day and left by lunch time .
I am not going to comment on the site as many of the reviews have already done so .
What I really found annoying about the place was that there were animal droppings all over the tracks .

Not only did we have to avoid the rocks and find correct footing , but we had to pay special attention to avoid stepping on the thousands of fly laden droppings that lined the entire route to the monastery .
I do not understand why the petra authorities do nothing to stop this from happening .

All they need to do is to enforce a rule that all animal handlers are required to equip the animals with poop collectors so that this beautiful attraction can be clean throughout and not smell like crap .
I paid a substantial amount to enter this attraction , this is the minimum standard I expect .
Of course a visit to Jordan would not be complete without visiting this wonderful , ancient site .
However , as well as spectacular tombs and temples and desert scenery you will also , sadly , see donkeys collapsing and dying of exhaustion before your eyes .
You will also see donkeys getting whipped with electrical cord , kicked until they bleed , suffering abscesses due to chains used to harness them and donkeys carrying incredibly heavy tourists .
I appreciate that these are working animals and that the local Bedouin need to make a living but this severe mistreatment really takes away from the experience .
On the one hand you are there to enjoy it peacefully on the other you have to witness distressing animal cruelty .
The place itself is very beautiful , the color of the stones is breathtaking , the hike is incredibly enjoyable .
My only problem was with the carriages driven by a horse used as means of transportation ( instead of walking ) inside Petra .
One of the horses stopped walking , the man tried to drag him and then when the horse stopped again he took a whip and started hitting him with it .
It was very painful I started shouting at him , told him that the horse was probably exhausted , that he simply can not move anymore , he said ironically ah really ?
He did not hit him again in front of me but I think that he just waited until I left .
I think that the ministry of tourism should really do something about it , in fact I would never go back there again .
Horses ( usually one ) are used to drive carriages carrying around four people .
In summer ( I went in July ) the tempreture there is around 40 degrees .
But seeing many horses being whipped to move faster or to move at all means that they do not .
If you go there please do not ride animals unless you have to ( age or people with problems walking ) .
I would also reccommend riding a horse and not a carriage for obvious reasons .
All the great photos and hype led to a disappointment on visiting Petra .
Too many pushy touts and begging kids to fight your way down to the wadi .
An early evening visit would have been better as light too bright forgood photos .
The heritage site is wonderful , but , because of long distance until monastery is very tiresome .
There are a lot of Bedouins asking for 10 jod to take you to the monastery , 20 jod from the monastery to the Treasury and 30 jod more from Treasury to a place near the exit .
From here another Bedouin ask you for money to take you the last 1,5km to the exit .
I think this is also unpleasant and for 50 jod ( 67 euro ) paid for the ticket , we could have much more better conditions inside Petra .
Also toilets are 1 jod per person which is not normal .
If we add to all of this bad smells and very dirty road inside the site due to donkeys , camels and horses , I can say , I did not have a pleasant experience in Petra .
This is not the first review here that mentions our problem with Petra .
The site is beautiful , but we could not enjoy it because of all the animal abuse .
At every 5 meters you will get offered a donkey ride , please do not do this .
you will see donkeys that carry too much weight , people ( a lot of small children as well ) that hit the donkeys , camels or horses for fun and donkeys being kicked .
The walk to the monastry is tough , but its worth it .
We did not took a tourguide , but i would recommened it as its easy and they tell you a lot of extra information .
you will spend the first half hour of your tour stuck in front of a large map at the visitors center instead of seeing the sights .
Our tour guide Jethro was most interested in directing us toward his cousins hiring donkeys and selling overpriced juice .
After the ride expect to be attacked if you tip less than 7 JOD per person for a 500 meter ride down to the entrance to the Siq .
I wish I could have seen it 50 or 100 years ago , before it became such a circus .
Walking through the sique to the iconic treasury in Petra is outstanding and astounding .
It is truly a wonder to experience and is highly recommended .
We spent around six hours scaling the site and meeting locals .
The only downside for me was witnessing the poor treatment of the animals who were there to transport tourists .
The horses had no access to water and were frothing at the mouth and sweating - they were also tripping and skidding trying to cart people in carriages up the hills .

We witnessed them being whipped constantly and although the signs at the entrance to the site clearly state they are for the benefit of people unable to walk the distance , the carriages were loaded wiht anyone willing to pay money .
The donkeys were also treated badly and I had to yell at a boy whipping a donkey in the face .
He hid himself behind his scarf so I could not photograph him .
Visit this amazing site but please do not support this disgusting treatment of animals .
What an amazing place but you really need to be fit and well to walk .
Firstly you must walk more than a mile down the Siq before you get to the Treasury , from that point there is so much more to see and you can easily do another 2 or 3 miles , then the walk back .
It is possible to take a horse and cart , camel or donkey but they do not seem to be treated too well , so that is something that you have to decide upon .
The place is quite amazing and each turn reveals something new .
We visited Petra for the day via a cruise ship docked at Aqaba .
First thing to say is the journey is scheduled for 2 hours but in reality due to regular serious accidents on the main highway it could be longer .
We took just under 2 hours getting there but coming back took just over 3 .
If you arrive by bus you will be dropped off at the bus park a couple of minutes a walk from the entrance and pleasant visitors centre , with information , toilets and some tourist shopping .
The first decision you need to make is how to get to the Siq , the entrance to the site which is perhaps a kilometre from the visitors centre .

Three choices , walk , pony / horse or pony and carriage , we chose to walk , the horse ride is included in the ticket although a tip is expected , the carriage ride for 2 was $ 25 , but apparently can change depending on how busy the site is .
Walking takes longer but you will miss some of the sights on the way the the Siq , the ground is uneven and it was hot when we visited in May .
The Siq is the entrance to Petra and is a long winding gorge that is simply beautiful , sadly for me that is when the awe ended .
The Siq opens out onto the Treasury , featured in an Indiana Jones film , but because of horses , carriages , camels and the gift shops it is devalued as a historical site .
Moving on from that area things improve with the tombs and amphitheatre , I would have loved to have visited the monestary but we were short of time and the climb seemed daunting .
There lies the problem a day is not enough we never saw the actual city site which stretches over several kilometers , you really need at least two full days to do this site justice .
All in all Petra did not wow me in the way for example Ephesus did but it is somewhere you should visit once even if it is just to experience the majesty of walking the Siq .
Street vendors are so boring and invasive , that we wished to leave Petra as fast as possible , they are a huge problem .
The place was too big , its a bit tiring , but nevertheless its something to see if you have a full day for it .
You are constantly being harassed by kids and adults to take a carriage ride or the donkeys .
They do not understand NO and since it was off season and not as many tourist to harass they would not leave us alone .
I live in the Middle East and am used to hagglers but to be honest I was extremely uncomfortable and felt a bit unsafe .
The tourist police just sat in their truck and did not make these people leave ( most still live in the caves and village around it ) .
We got about an hour in , took the pictures of the sights we wanted to see and left .
Petra ruins are a lot much better in quality of tombs , dimension of the whole site , and beauty of the natural canyon that you can expect , reading any guide or seeing any film .

Among the people who live there , bedouins in some way , there are very cruel teenagers - they love , really enjoy beating donkeys and feeling themselves the masters , specially if tourists are looking at them .
it is even worse if you try to talk with them , asking for stopping .
Then they beat the donkey as crazy , not matter that tourist police is just there , Once we were talking with one young , maybe just 14 years old .
You can never rely on a donkey , you have to beat it - look at me !
And he went away doing it once and again to show his freedom , his loneliness .
Those scenes and the general treatment - keeping them all day tied , with the tiniest rope , under the sun , even with their bloody feets tied , was horrible .
We could not understand how people could want to ride them We have been in a lot of countries in Asia and Africa with economic and social problems .
Places where one can see that life is extremely difficult for people .
However we are not talking about that , this was cruelty and spoiled our visit to Petra .
We stayed in Sharm el Sheikh and did a ( very long and tiring ) day trip to Petra , and the long journey was very much worth it .
I was absolutely appalled by the condition of the animals on the site .
The vast majority of horses , donkeys and camels seemed underfed , mistreated and exhausted .
They have to work hard the entire day , and did not seem to get any water .
Not getting water is fine for the camels , but horses and donkeys really do need to drink .
We saw various animals with wounds and pretty much all of them had large scars of old wounds .
Everytime someone takes a horse or carriage to go down , the handlers make them gallop as fast as possible back up to take the next passenger .
Especially the horses of the carriages seemed in a really bad shape .
We saw a lot of horses and donkeys getting hit incessantly .
I used to ride horses for a number of years and I acknowledge that sometimes a whip can be useful , however it should never be used constantly nor which so much force .
The guy of the carriages ( number 2 ) kept hitting his horse to go harder whilst the animal was completely drenched in sweat .
Not only is this dangerous ( also to other people and horses around it it is pure animal cruelty .
We were shocked that this is allowed to continue at a site that is so famous and probably a big source of income from tourism .
I have sent a complaint to the official Petra site about this , and I would urge anyone to please not use the animals .
Other than this , the site was amazing and really worth the visit , but that part really spoiled it for us .
Petra is one of the once in a life time experience .
It was just an amazing site that its hard to put it in words .
First of all , I saw people falling off the donkey and got injured because the cobble stone roads are very slippery .
Second of all which is very sad that the donkeys are controlled by children .
I saw a child stabbing a donkey with a stick and the donkey was bleeding , howling and clearly in pain .
Anyway , please do visit Petra , but Please please do not use any animals .
a very nice place to visit , be prepared to do a lot of walking which could be too much for some people .
also try to do the visit by night which is a completely different experience .
We have seen many of the ancient sites now and there are very few left on our list .
We can now say we have seen one of the greatest ancient historic sites in the world .
I think to attempt to verbalise this wonderful place would be beyond the scope of a Tripadvisor review .
Suffice to say there many thousand photo's on the internet which would do more justice than a few hundred words or a couple of my amateur pics .
However no picture can truly instill the sheer grandeur and scale of the site - you have to see it to feel it .
However do not bother with the Petra by Night show - it is a pure ripoff .
We were just passing through and connected with an agent on Facebook .

He picked us up at the Amman airport and drove us straight to Petra , the next day he picked us up and drove to the Israel border where he connected us with a guide to tour Jerusalem , Bethlehem and Jericho .
We crammed as much as we could to 2 days , but Nader made it possible .
You need at least 4-5 days in Jordan , and at least 1 week in Israel to really soak everything in , but we saw the main sights in 2 days and look forward to coming back some day to see the rest .
Visited Petra via the backdoor trail was a nice hike and amazingly beautiful .
We started at 7:00 because it would get hot and a long walk .
Despite a knee-injury of one of our family members the track was doable .

From the monastery downward to the other highlights the stairs were steep and we could have taken a donkey or horse ride down , but we did not as the these poor animals were firmly approached by their owners ( sad to see ) .
Nevertheless , the highlights keep one amazing by their dimensions and architectonic ingenuity for those ancient days .
Its a must when visiting Jordan , which you will never regret .
Petra , the capital of the Nabataean Empire from the 1st century BC .
Petra was later annexed to the Roman Empire and continued to thrive until a large earthqake in 363AD destroyed much of the city in the 4th century AD .
Petra is also known as the rose-red city , a name it gets ftom the wonderful colour of the rock from which many of the city's structures were carved .
You need a lot of time and energy to see everything .
The souvenirs on side are really cheap compared to the local shops in Petra .
We hire a dunkeyes , because we were very tired from the climbing and the heat .
The local men send his 9 years old boy to navigate the donkeys on our way .
Poor boy it is only 9 years old climbing like daily like 5000 steps at least and 30-40 km .
On the way we were feeling so guilty and steped down from the donkeys and returned then to the little boy .
He works from early morning to the late evening every day Tips .
The water on side cost 1-2 JDGo early when the heat is not so strong and less tourist .
You will need ID card or Passport to enter in Petra .
We spent just 5 hours in the archaeological site and saw just the main attractions !
You have to stay for several hours there to be able to see much more !
A local tour guide is useful for learning enough about the history of the place !
Petra had always been on my bucket list and I have watched many documentaries about it .
We spent 5 hours there , and walked for 12 kms seeing only the highlights .
Had we known , we would have spent 2 days there .
We went there end of June which is the very low season , so no crowds ( yesss ) but it was quite hot ( 38 degrees ) .
Fortunately , there are lots of places where you can buy water .
do not hesitate to hire one of the local guides , you will enjoy the visit so much more !
We were informed that your groups often visit tue , wed and thur so if you want it to be quieter avoid these days .
This place is just amazing if you are into walking / hiking and history !
Just keep in mind that some of them are far apart and it takes a lot of walking to get there , which is not that easy in the heat if your not used to it .
do not forget to take enough water and cash with you .
You will eventually run out of water , as it is impossible to carry enough water for the whole day .
We went through 3 litres each , so we had to buy water there hence the cash .
There are plenty shops across the place where you can buy water which is super important .

The local Bedouin people unfortunately have a stall nearly everywhere and sometimes they get a bit pushy with selling their stuff , but if you are used to Egypt then this will feel like a breeze , as they are not as bad in Petra .

You will be offered plenty donkey / horse and camel rides which are technically free , but they do expect a fee as this is their sole income , so keep that in mind , otherwise it might get quite awkward once you are there .
The place is super clean and they are trying to look after it .
The entry prices are not cheap , but I would recommend buying a Jordan Pass instead of a normal Visa , because that Jordan Pass covers 2 days in Petra which is much more reasonable .
All in all I would definitely recommend this place , but keep in mind that we walked about 15km a day in the heat , which is not for everybody .
You can take it a bit easier of course , but then you will see less , so you might want to consider an additional day to cover it all .
Having a good guide who details the history of the place makes it more worthwhile .
We did a day at Petra as a cruise ship excursion .
We chose Trek to the Monastery , as it was the longest in duration and we wanted to see as much as we could on this once in a lifetime bucket list trip !
I have to say we were a little unprepared for the heat , crowds , size and terrain !
Maybe not unprepared , we would done a fair bit of research , I think we were maybe a bit overwhelmed !
I am so glad I worked hard to improve my fitness before we travelled .
I was not prepared for the length or gradient of the walk from the visitor centre , what goes down , must come up !
That was hard work in the heat after trekking for many hours !
I have always wanted to visit Petra and it was just so much more than I expected .
To think that at it is zenith , when there were 300 million people in the world , 30000 lived in Petra .
To me personally , absolutely one of the seven wonders of the modern world .
Our guide was excellent and gave us so much detailed information that I would recommend visitors do take advantage of a guide to make the most of the experience .
I would not have appreciated as much as I did without information .
Also , having a guide really helped to make the walk down into Petra less daunting for elderly or less fit people .
It was hot , it was dusty , it was important to drink water - which you can buy en route , you do not have to carry vast amounts .
Our guide knew to set off early in the day to avoid the crowds and to go down in the cooler air .
It was a wise decision as we could see on our return walk when it was very hot and a lot of people were finding it tough going .
We were not warned , but do be aware of pickpockets .
As I walked up it was crowded in the narrow areas and as I stopped for a drink could see that both zips on my backpack had been opened as I was walking .
Nothing had been taken however I should have been more aware of the dangers .
This is one of those places that has become so justifiably famous and popular that if you get the chance you simply have to go .
There are important things to bear in mind on any visit which I am sure have been touched on by other reviewers but are worth repeating nevertheless to ensure you are prepared .
First of all , having arrived at entrance or the car park , you have a long walk ahead of you - dress sensibly particularly footwear because some of the paths are uneven and slippery .

As you pass through the impressive Siq ( a narrow gorge with steep rocks either side ) watch out for carts , horses , donkeys and camels that come careering along carrying visitors who would rather pay for transport rather than walk .
The Treasury looms magically into view and you then realise what all the fuss is about .
Bear in mind that if you are on a day trip you will not be able to see all that Petra has to offer but the sight of the Treasury really makes it all worthwhile .
Remember that going back to the entrance is uphill so pace yourself accordingly .
Take plenty of water and do not believe the people in charge of the donkeys when they say the price is included in your ticket ( as I heard ) because it is not .
Finally the souvenirs ( including the designs made from sand in a bottle ) are cheaper outside the main gates than in Petra itself - unless you are an accomplished bargainer .
Finally - enjoy one of the seven wonders of the modern world !

Petra , located in southern Jordan , in the basin of mountain range , is a historical & archeological city believed to have been inhabited from 9000BC .
Since it was in the proximity of trade routes , the Nabataean Kingdom ( nomadic Arabs ) established it as a major regional trading hub .
The Nabateans were skilled at rainwater harvesting , agriculture & stone carving as spectacularly evidenced by the site .
The famous Treasury building ( Khazneh structure ) was built in 1st century AD .
Petras importance as a trading hub declined with emerging sea trade routes and many structures were destroyed in the 363AD earthquake .
Many Christian churches were built in the Byzantine era , but Petra continued to decline and was abandoned by early Islamic era .
It became unknown to the world until it was rediscovered in 1812 .
It is a UNESCO world heritage centre and in 2007 was named among the New seven wonders of the world .

Originally from America she has lived in a local Bedouin village for the last 5 years and provides a fantastic bridge into the language ( she is fluent in 8 languages including Arabic ) and people and culture of Jordan .
Her knowledge having majored in Ancient History was way above our simple questions , however her love of Jordan was obvious and contagious !
From Little Petra we took a donkey ride across some amazing terrain and viewpoints to enter Petra the back way via the Monastery .
The donkey ride was epic in itself , and the scenery stunning , which helped distract you from the feeling that the donkey was intent on a suicidal leap off any given rock at any particular moment !
Nevertheless the first view of the Monastery made it all worth it , and again arriving here first we had it pretty much to ourselves .
From here we took the hour and a half-ish route DOWN the valley which we soon noticed was a major bonus over the hoards of people coming the other way facing a hot uphill trek .
A local Bedouin , born and raised within Petra itself , he took us the alternative ways and showed us routes around the whole site that were away from the main throng of people .
He told us all about their way of life and kept us laughing and entertained with his tin whistle and precarious head stands !

Of course eventually you have to be where everyone else is if you want to get up close to it all , and our final stop at the Treasury by 4pm meant the light was very soft and we could sit and enjoy it without roasting .
The walk back out through the Siq ( beautiful gorge leading into the site ) gave us enough time to reflect on everything we would seen whilst being not too uphill for our now weary feet !
Dinner outside the site with Ibrahim , Rebecca and our driver Nasir was followed by watching the sunset over the desert , with tea , traditional music , dancing and laughter !
We were promised the Real Bedouin Experience and we definitely got it !

The people we met showed us so much hospitality and welcoming that we felt we came away not only having seen one of the most beautiful places in the world but also having made lovely friends in Jordan !
